thread.title: Julie Bishop's emoji take on Putin questioned by Senators
thread.title_full: Julie Bishop's emoji take on Putin questioned by Senators | afr.com

author: Share via Email
title: Julie Bishop's emoji take on Putin questioned by Senators
text:
Foreign Affairs minister Julie Bishop possibly texting emojis during question time. Andrew Meares Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Foreign Minister Julie Bishop's use of a red-face man emoji to describe Russian President Vladimir Putin during an emoji-only interview has come under question in an extended session in federal parliament.
During a strictly-pictorial interview with Buzzfeed News , Ms Bishop was asked what she thought of Mr Putin, to which she responded simply with a red-faced man emoji.
As Attorney General George Brandis suggested "the nation hangs transfixed" by the line of questioning, Labor Senator Penny Wong suggested this was not particularly diplomatic.
"Do you think that's a helpful public statement?" she asked.
Wong says this is the point of emoji questioning. She asks DFAT "do you think that's a helpful public statement"? pic.twitter.com/Pwo85T6N0x
â€” Primrose Riordan (@primroseriordan) October 21, 2015 Senator Chris Back never having heard the term emoji or Buzzfeed News , Brandis helpfully explained they were "smiley faces that you have on your text messages", while Senator Sam Dastyari suggested he pop Mr Back's emoji cherry by messaging him one.
Senator Brandis then said that "context is everything" when it came to Ms Bishop's interview, while DFAT asked to take on notice what the meaning of a red faced emoji was - leaving Labor incredulous.
Senator Wong also asked if DFAT ever use emojis in diplomatic negotiations, to which DFAT secretary Peter Varghese, said "well I'm not aware of any such usage" before referring to his department's social media chief.
DFAT have since confirmed they veer into pictures to achieve global cut through.
Happy to provide @SenatorWong ðŸ˜³ with a translation of emoji to a language Labor understands ðŸ˜Ž
â€” Julie Bishop (@JulieBishopMP) October 21, 2015 Mr Varghese, a former High Commissioner to India and Malaysia, said he had not seen the article, and under questioning said he did not use emojis in his communications.
"So you're an emoji-free zone," Senator Wong jived.
â€‹Ms Bishop, not in the hearing, then hit back saying she's "happy to provide Senator Wong with a translation of emoji to a language Labor understands".
Burn.
